description.narrative: Capacity of justice and security institutions enhanced and linkages forged through enhancing capacities of justice actors.

participating-org.narrative: UNITED NATIONS DEVELOPMENT FUND FOR WOMEN (UN WOMEN)

activity-description.narrative: Capacity of justice and security institutions enhanced and linkages forged.

provider-org.narrative: UNITED NATIONS DEVELOPMENT FUND FOR WOMEN (UN WOMEN)

condition.narrative: Social and environmental sustainability will be enhanced through application of the UNDP Social and Environmental Standards (http://www.undp.org/ses) and related Accountability Mechanism (http://www.undp.org/secu-srm).

description.narrative:
Number of justice and security sector personnel dis-aggregated by gender, age, education attainment and location
Number of women employed by different justice and security institutions.

comment.narrative:
Limited presence reached and capacity of the different justice and security institutions, particularly in outlying areas
Lack of public awareness of the roles and responsibilities of the different justice and security institutions

1.1.1 Provide technical support, capacity building and service delivery support to specialised Courts E and juvenile courts in selected counties and magisterial court at Rivercess 1.1.2 Establish a case management system to ensure efficient disposal of cases, reduce case backlog and support online court communication 1.1.3 Support the establishment of magisterial sitting programme (mobile courts) and monitoring programme mobile courts to reduce prolonged and arbitrary detention 1.1.4 Support the development of a simplified information system to enhance transparency and access to the court 1.1.5 Support the Judiciary Training Institute to roll out the Women Human Rights (WHR) training modules 1.1.6 Mainstream gender into the JTI by developing an institutional gender policy/strategy 1.2.1 Support the establishment of a comprehensive legal aid system and an independent legal aid board through a legal aid Act 1.2.2 Support the rule law coordinating mechanisms through the PPMU 1.2.3 Provide technical and logistical support to the SGBV Crimes Unit to prosecute GBV cases in Criminal Court E 1.2.4 Support the establishment of a functional case management system at the Directorate of Public Prosecution 1.2.5: Support the strengthening and gender sensitivity of alternative dispute resolution mechanisms and training of traditional leaders 1.2.6. Support the implementation of the gender policy of the Ministry of Justice and strengthen the capacity of the gender unit and other departments on gender, FGM and Gender Responsive budgeting 1.3.1 Provide technical support to the police to develop competencies in gender and child responsive policing 1.3.2: Provide technical and logistical support to the WACPS to ensure the investigation of cases 1.3.3 Support the management (collection, analysis, storage, retrieval and dissemination) of crime statistics 1.3.4: Support the roll out of the LNP gender policy 1.4.1 Provide technical support for the enactment of a new prisons Act 1.4.2 Provide capacity building support for Correction Officers on human rights, prisons management and inmate care. 1.4.3 Support the provision of vocational training and educational services to female and male inmates 1.4.4 Support the provision of technical support and training to probation officers to improve the probation services 1.4.5 Conduct studies and comparative analysis on alternatives to imprisonment and pre-trial detention. 1.4.6. Support the implementation of the Bureau for Corrections and Rehabilitation’s gender policy and strengthen the capacity of the Gender unit 1.5.1: Conduct specialised trainings on gender and human rights, anti-human trafficking, border management and migration for LIS personnel 1.5.2: Support the conduct of entry level examinations for commissioned and non-commissioned officers of LIS to promote its specialisation 1.5.3. Strengthen the capacity of the Gender Unit and provide technical support to implement the existing gender strategy 2.1.1 Support the establishment of 2 Justice and Confidence Centres for the provision of legal aid services, psychosocial support and human rights awareness to survivors on SGBV 2.1.2: Partners with the LNBA to respond to pre-trial detention trough legal aid clinics 2.1.3: Establish a network of women CSOs and support the network and INCHR to provide awareness on and monitor the Courts E 2.1.4: Support the implementation of the national SGBV road map 2.1.5: Support efforts to finalize the establishment of a legal aid clinic at the Louis Arthur Grimes Law School at the University of Liberia 2.2.1: Conduct capacity assessment of selected CSOs delivering legal aid services with emphasis on women led CSOs. 2.2.2: Build the capacity of CSOs with emphasis on female led CSOs and other legal aid providers based on the assessment findings 2.2.3: Provide specialized training for judges, prosecutors, investigators, lawyers, victim support staff/social workers and forensic/medical staff providing pro bono services to survivors of GBV 3.1.1 Support INCHR to monitor, investigate and document human rights violations and abuses 3.1.2 Support the implementation of NHRAP 3.1.3 Support INCHR and Human Rights Department of the Ministry of Justice to monitor and advocate for the implementation of UPR, Treaty bodies and United Nations Special Procedure recommendations 3.1.4 Support the domestication of the Convention on the Rights of Children (CRC) Optional Protocols, and raising the minimum age of criminal responsibility to support law reforms in the country 3.1.5 Provide support to Civil Society Organizations Human Rights Advocacy Platform to monitor, document and report human rights violations and abuse across the counties in Liberia 3.1.6: Support development of regulatory framework and civil society network to prevent and respond to violence and discrimination against LGBTI persons 3.2.1 Conduct study on factors that fuel corruption and their patterns 3.2.2 Support legal, policy and institutional reforms and capacity enhancement of the LACC and its personnel 3.2.3 Train and support CSOs and the media to monitor and investigate corruption cases 3.2.4 Support the establishment of an e-platform that enables anonymous reporting of corruption cases to relevant government institutions and departments and tracks follow up actions taken 3.2.5: Conduct perception survey to ascertain citizens perceptions on access to justice

1.1.1 Constructed one modern Magisterial Court in Yarkpa’s Town, Rivercess County. 1.1.2 Established one Case Management Information System at the Judiciary to ensure efficient disposal of cases, reduce case backlog and support online court communication 1.1.4 Developed and installed 50 pieces of information bulletin board to displays court fees and fines for the Judiciary 1.2.1 Draft and submitted a Legal Aid Bill to the Office of the President for onward submission to the National Legislature. 1.2.2 Provided technical and material support to PPMU that supported the Unit to conduct three rule of law coordinating meeting 1.2.4 Established one functional Case Management Information System at the Directorate of Public Prosecution 1.2.5: Developed a harmonized and standardized training manual on the application of human rights, gender equity and laws to the resolution of disputes for traditional authorities. 1.3.2: Provided office equipment, office and stationery supplies to the Women and Children Protection Section (WACPS) of the Liberia National Police to ensure the investigation of cases 1.3.3 Developed online Crime Statistics Information System for the Liberia National Police and produced 2000 copies of the Crime Statistics Reports. 1.4.1 Provided technical support and revised the Bill titled “National Corrections and Rehabilitation Services Act of 2019” seeking to make the BCR semi-autonomous. 1.4.2 Supported the training of 64 corrections officers (47 men and 17 women) on human rights, prisons management and inmate care. 1.4.4 Conducted awareness activities on probation and parole services that benefited 192 (64 men and 28 women) and expanded visibility for the acceptance and functions of probation and parole services. 1.4.5 Conducted a study to comparatively analyze alternatives to imprisonment and pre-trial detention using country, regional and international perspectives. 1.5.1: Supported the conduct of specialized trainings on gender and human rights, anti-human trafficking, border management and migration for 233 apprentice LIS personnel (195 men and 38 women) 2.1.1 Supported the establishment of 3 Justice and Confidence Centers and provided legal aid services psychosocial support to 624 (326 men and 298 women), as well as educated 110,299 persons on human rights, legal aid services and prevention and response to GBV. 2.1.3: Established two women led CSO networks-one each in Bong and Nimba. Supported the CSO networks and partners to create awareness on Court E, GBV prevention and response, monitored the performance of Court E and supported survivors to access needed services through the referral pathways, contributing to reaching the 110, 299 persons reached by the Programme during the year. 2.2.1: Conducted one capacity needs assessment of 32 selected women led CSOs delivering legal aid services to survivors and other vulnerable groups. 2.2.2: Conducted one capacity building training for 32 persons for 32 women led CSOs on legal aid, human rights, advocacy, proposal writing, etc. 3.2.1 Commissioned and is implementing a study on factors that fuel corruption and their patterns. 3.2.2 Supported the drafting of two bills seeking to give the Liberia Anti-Corruption Commission (LACC) legal power to directly prosecute corruption cases and protect whistle blowers. 3.2.4 Supported the establishment of an e-platform that enables anonymous reporting of corruption cases to relevant government institutions and departments and tracks follow up actions taken 3.2.5: Commissioned and is implementing a survey to ascertain public perceptions on the performance of, trust and confidence in, and satisfaction with justice and security institutions.
